channel.title: NYT > Movies Our reviews
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Kevin Costner’s ‘Horizon’ Is Debuting Friday. Will Audiences Follow?
item.description: To make “Horizon,” he put his own money on the line and left “Yellowstone,” the series that revived his career — all with little Hollywood support.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling

item.title: ‘White Chicks’ at 20: Comedy Beyond the Pale
item.description: The Wayans brothers’ subversive comedy is smarter than you remember.
item.dc:creator: Robert Daniels
item.media:description: Marlon Wayans and Shawn Wayans in “White Chicks.”

item.title: ‘I Am: Celine Dion’ Review: You Saw the Best in Me
item.description: Dion’s voice made her a star. A new documentary on Amazon Prime Video brings her back to Earth, showing her intimate struggles with stiff person syndrome.
item.dc:creator: Chris Azzopardi

item.title: ‘The Lion King’ at 30: Jason Weaver Sang for Simba but Few Knew It
item.description: The actor was playing a young Michael Jackson when Elton John spotted him. Three decades later, the new attention to his legacy is “gratifying.”
item.dc:creator: Ashley Spencer
item.media:description: Jason Weaver, right, who brought Simba’s songs to life in the original “Lion King,” with Ernie Sabella, left, and Nathan Lane, the actors who voiced Pumbaa and Timon.

item.title: “Inside Out 2” Understands How Anxiety Effects Me
item.description: In a way that’s both cathartic and devastating, Pixar’s latest portrays how anxiety can take hold, our critic writes.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips

item.title: Jonathan Majors Is Cast in First Movie Role Since Assault Conviction
item.description: Mr. Majors, who was sentenced to a year of domestic violence programming and was dropped by Marvel, is set to star in the independent thriller “Merciless.”
item.dc:creator: Reggie Ugwu
item.media:description: Jonathan Majors’s notable roles include “The Last Black Man in San Francisco,” “Creed III” and “Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania.”

item.title: How Netflix’s Corporate Culture Has Changed
item.description: The company’s latest internal memo about its corporate culture is more about how it expects employees to behave than what it wants to become.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new memo highlights Netflix’s philosophy of “People Over Process” first: “We hire unusually responsible people who thrive on this openness and freedom.”

item.title: Russell Crowe’s in 2 Exorcism Films? Yes, and Here’s Why the Roles Work
item.description: In a three-decade career, he’s developed an impressive range without forgetting how to have fun.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza
item.category: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (Movie)

item.title: It’s the Summer of Powell and Pressburger in New York
item.description: The British filmmaking team were maestros of Technicolor and so much more. If you don’t know their work, your favorite directors do.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: Alec Baldwin’s Long Journey to Court After ‘Rust’ Shooting
item.description: It’s been a challenge to follow the case. Here are its many twists and turns.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Mahler

item.title: Celine Dion Can Only Be Herself
item.description: The singer’s over-the-top sincerity and expressiveness were once seen as irredeemably uncool. In the new documentary “I Am: Celine Dion,” they have become her superpowers.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:description: Since her emergence as a Québécois child star, something about Celine Dion’s essential nature has remained constant, impervious to both changing trends and scathing critique.

item.title: The Long, Strange Road to Alec Baldwin’s Manslaughter Trial
item.description: After an accidental on-set shooting death — and two years of bitter legal combat — the movie star is about to have his day in court.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Mahler

item.title: Kino Film Collection, a Streaming Alternative to Netflix and Hulu
item.description: The service is an art house answer to what’s missing on some of the more popular streamers.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey

item.title: ‘I Am: Celine Dion’ Director Talks About Capturing the Star’s Seizure
item.description: Irene Taylor, director of the new documentary “I Am: Celine Dion,” talks about the decision to include a grueling scene of the pop star in crisis.
item.dc:creator: Annie Aguiar

item.title: Film Academy Chief Gets a Sequel: Bill Kramer’s Contract Is Renewed
item.description: Amid challenges in Hollywood, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences renewed its chief executive’s contract a year early.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.category: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

item.title: Kevin Costner Will Not Return to ‘Yellowstone’
item.description: The actor and director is turning his attention to his ambitious film series about post-Civil War America.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam
item.media:description: “I just realized that I’m not going to be able to continue Season Five B or into the future,” Kevin Costner said about his participation in the final episodes of “Yellowstone.”

item.title: 15 Donald Sutherland Movies to Stream: ‘Hunger Games,’ ‘M*A*S*H’ and More
item.description: Whether in the lead or a supporting role, the actor’s immense talent and range were apparent in six decades of performances.
item.dc:creator: Scott Tobias
item.media:description: Donald Sutherland delivered sarcasm and soul in “M*A*S*H.”

item.title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include demon baby, a cursed chef and all kinds of people trapped in hellish situations.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg

item.title: Conan O’Brien Doesn’t Matter
item.description: *That’s his opinion. And yet he’s setting a new standard for what life after late-night can look like. (Hint: It’s a lot like what he did on talk shows.)
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman
item.category: Conan O'Brien Needs a Friend (Radio Program)
item.media:credit: Adali Schell for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen Colbert said O’Brien expanded the limits of silliness in late-night. He’s “all rubber chicken, no knife,” Colbert said.

item.title: 7 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: A Universe of Inspirations Swirls Within ‘Janet Planet’
item.description: The playwright Annie Baker shares the artistic influences behind her feature film debut.
item.dc:creator: Robert Ito

item.title: ‘Copa 71’ Documentary Shows Hidden History of Women’s World Cup
item.description: This new documentary unearths footage from a World Cup event that even veteran players didn’t know about. It’s both exhilarating and infuriating.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: Donald Sutherland Didn’t Disappear Into Roles, and That Was a Good Thing
item.description: The actor understood the range of human feeling, but he came of age when movies distrusted institutions, and that suspicion was part of his arsenal.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: Donald Sutherland, a Chameleon of a Movie Star, Dies at 88
item.description: In a wide-ranging career (from “M*A*S*H” to “Ordinary People” to “The Hunger Games”), he could be endearing in one role, menacing in another and just plain odd in a third.
item.dc:creator: Clyde Haberman
item.media:credit: Jack Robinson/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Donald Sutherland in a 1970 publicity photo. He said he was once rejected for a film role by a producer who said: “This part calls for a guy-next-door type. You don’t look like you’ve lived next door to anyone.”

item.title: ‘Green Border’ Review: Migrants’ Elusive Race for Freedom
item.description: Agnieszka Holland focuses on the Polish-Belarusian border as a Syrian family tries to make it to the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘Federer: Twelve Final Days’ Review: Roger, Over and Out
item.description: A new documentary follows the Swiss tennis star from his 2022 retirement announcement to his final match.
item.dc:creator: Amy Nicholson

item.title: ‘Hummingbirds’ Review: Two Friends’ Summer Along the Border
item.description: The young directors Silvia Del Carmen Castaños and Estefanía (Beba) Contreras stargaze, watch fireworks and discuss their lives in this documentary filmed in Laredo, Texas.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘Thelma’ Review: Granny Get Your Gun
item.description: The remarkable June Squibb plays a vengeful scam victim in this ludicrous action-movie spoof.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis
item.media:description: From left, June Squibb in the title role and Fred Hechinger as her grandson in a scene from the film “Thelma.”

item.title: ‘The Devil’s Bath’ Review: Madwoman in the Cottage
item.description: This stark psychological horror movie tracks the mental deterioration of an 18th-century peasant woman.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza

item.title: ‘Kinds of Kindness’ Review: Everybody’s Looking for Something
item.description: Yorgos Lanthimos returns with a twisted fable triptych about dominating and being dominated.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘The Exorcism’ Review: Losing Faith
item.description: Russell Crowe stars as an actor playing an exorcist who’s battling his own demons.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Janet Planet’ Review: A Sticky Summer Full of Small Dramas
item.description: Annie Baker’s debut feature film is a tiny masterpiece — a perfect coming-of-age story for both a misfit tween and her mother.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘The Bikeriders’ Review: On the Road to Nowhere, Beautifully
item.description: Austin Butler, Jodie Comer and Tom Hardy star in a romanticized drama about a fictional motorcycle club in the 1960s.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis
